screens.headline: Iron condor = shotgun. Butterfly = sniper.
screens.text: Want a low-cost, high-precision bet on a specific target price? Butterflies shine when you expect a pin.

screens.headline: Butterfly = Target a specific price at expiration
screens.text: Structure (calls): Buy 1 ITM call, Sell 2 ATM calls, Buy 1 OTM call â€” same expiration, equidistant strikes. Net debit: small. Max profit at the middle strike; max loss is the small debit you paid.

screens.headline: Precision bet vs. wide net
screens.text: Butterfly: small entry cost, high payoff if you hit the bullseye. Iron condor: you get paid upfront, but profit is spread across a wider zone with lower peak.

cards.definition: Lower = lower strike + debit; Upper = upper strike - debit.

screens.question: Main difference vs iron condor?
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly. Butterflies focus profit at a price target; condors spread profit over a wider range.
screens.explanation_wrong: Butterflies are debit trades with narrow profit zones centered on the middle strike.

screens.headline: P/L at target
screens.question: With $95/$100/$105 butterfly costing $1, what is profit at $100?
screens.explanation: At $100: lower call worth $5; short calls $0; upper call $0. Value $5 minus $1 debit = $4 profit.
screens.teaching_point: Butterflies peak at the middle strike.
